abstract.p: Letter by Travelocity president Terrell B Jones objects to be grouped with online air reservations sites that are not operated honestly, comment on Nov 26 (2000) report (S)

block.p: To the Editor: We read with disappointment David Cay Johnston's article ''Navigating the Web for Air Fare Bargains'' (Correspondent's Report, Nov. 26).

The article quotes Paul Stephen Dempsey, vice chairman of Frontier Airlines, as saying ''there is no prohibition against deceitful practices'' at Internet air fare sites, and ''no obligation that these sites provide the lowest fares or best routings.''
To the Editor: We read with disappointment David Cay Johnston's article ''Navigating the Web for Air Fare Bargains'' (Correspondent's Report, Nov. 26).

The article quotes Paul Stephen Dempsey, vice chairman of Frontier Airlines, as saying ''there is no prohibition against deceitful practices'' at Internet air fare sites, and ''no obligation that these sites provide the lowest fares or best routings.''

However, the Department of Transportation has in place anti-bias regulations that govern the computer reservations systems (C.R.S.) used by travel agents, and it is considering extending these regulations to online travel agents. In a Senate Commerce Committee hearing in July, Travelocity testified that it voluntarily complies with these C.R.S. rules and therefore does not ''bias'' its flight displays.
We are actively involved in the effort to have these rules extended to all online travel sites.

We have even undertaken the extraordinary step of commissioning an independent audit of our flight display procedures. Unfortunately, we were grouped with all the other online travel sites in your report.
TERRELL B. JONES President and C.E.O., Travelocity Fort Worth
